description: An ancient oasis and trading city with monumental remains, located in modern Syria. Inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1980.
details:
The Barrington Atlas Directory notes: Tudmur

 
Inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1980 under criteria i, ii, and iv of UNESCO's World Heritage List Operational Guidelines.

Specific archaeological components include:

    • Art and architecture which in the 1st and 2nd centuries AD combined cultural influences from Graeco-Roman,local, and Persian traditions
    • A 1100 meter-long grand colonnaded street
    • Temple of Ba'al, Camp of Diocletian, an ancient Agora, and theatre
    • Various other temples and urban quarters
    • Unique examples of funerary sculpture which combine Graeco-Roman art with indigenous elements and Persian influence
    • Remains of a Roman aqueduct and immense necropoleis

history.comment: Retitle to just "Palmyra". Other names remain searchable.
Location updates and tags from Johan Ahlfeldt's (jahlfeldt) Digital Atlas of the Roman Empire in October 2012
Global migration and reindexing of citations and provenance, February 2012
New locations, coordinates, and metadata from Harvard's DARMC project. See http://atlantides.org/trac/pleiades/wiki/PlaceUpgradesAndMigrations
Detail text updated from former modernLocation. See http://atlantides.org/trac/pleiades/wiki/PlaceDetailsUpgrade

names.description: Palmyra, a Greek name of uncertain origin.

history.comment: Global migration and reindexing of citations and provenance, February 2012

names.description: Thadamora, name attested only by Josephus and attributed by him to "the Syrians" (he claims the Greeks referred to the city exclusively as "Palmyra").

history.comment: More details in support of the name that appears in the Barrington.
Global migration and reindexing of citations and provenance, February 2012

names.description: Hadrianopolis, title adopted by Palmyra in honor of the Roman emperor Hadrian.

history.comment: Global migration and reindexing of citations and provenance, February 2012

names.description: Palmyrenos, ethnic name for a citizen of Palmyra.
Latin name after the Greek. Still used in the west to designate the ancient city and its archaeological remains.
Tadmor, Hebrew name attested in 2 Chronicles; alternatively Tamar, a textual variant in the consonantal text of 1 Kings 9:19).
A place name from the TAVO Index (Vol. 3, p. 1560)
